results.title: William Shakespeare, background for his works
results.brief_description: Shows the places of Shakespeare’s times and the elements of his English life that gave the poet-playwright his language and shaped his character. Kenilworth Castle, Stratford, the River Avon, the Anne Hathaway cottage and a model of the original Globe Theatre are portrayed. Brief episodes are presented from some of the plays of Shakespeare: “Romeo and Juliet”, “Macbeth”, “Taming of the Shrew”, “The Merchant of Venice”, and “Hamlet”.

results.title: Why wilderness?
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Seymour High School and Shepparton South Technical School
results.brief_description: Footage by students from Seymour High School and Shepparton South Technical School depicts the southwest of Tasmania. Commentary emphasises the importance for man to explore his surroundings and enjoy nature.

results.title: Why I sing: the words and music of Gilles Vigneault
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Le troubadour de Natashquan, singer, songwriter, one-man show - Gilles Vigneault is one of the most popular entertainers in French Canada. He sweeps the audience along with his irrepressible exuberance, every so often breaking into a little jig around the microphone. In this film you get to know him even more intimately than does his theatre audience. His serious side emerges when he speaks of the themes of his songs (the internationally popular Mon Pays is one of these).
results.title_for_label: Why I sing: the words and music of Gilles Vigneault

results.title: The Whole world over
results.creator_credit: Don Haldane, Leonard Forest, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A trio of stories, set in three of the world’s great cities. Illustrates the theme that people, no matter who they are, or where they live, share the basic human qualities of love, kindness, generosity and compassion. Shows a teenage girl in Amsterdam, a hard-pressed business man in Montreal and a wistful little boy in Mexico City in episodes displaying their response to other people’s needs.

results.title: The Whole world is watching
results.brief_description: An examination of the question of bias in television newscasting. Network executives and reporters discuss such topics as advertising influences on news content, where the responsibility for good news reporting lies, and whether or not television reports news or attempts to make it. Documents what has become a continuing discussion of television newscasters and balanced material.

results.title: Who dares wins: men of the Special Air Service Regiment
results.brief_description: The title of this film is the motto of the Special Air Service Regiment, or SAS as it is commonly known. These men of the Australian Army possess specialist skills which are utilised, together with further training, to mould an elite fighting force. Shows their primary role in reconnaissance, surveillance and harassment of an enemy.

results.title: Where there's a will...
results.creator_credit: Cine-Service and Victorian Society for Crippled Children and Adults
results.brief_description: The work of the Victorian Society for Crippled Children and Adults in helping the physically handicapped to learn full, happy and as far as possible, independent lives. The Society tries to reach handicapped children early, so that they may benefit from training and companionship in special play centres. Special schools and holiday camps are organised for older children, while Deva Hostel and its annexe provide a home for handicapped young adults from the country, enabling them to further their education and compete for employment. More severely handicapped people are able to work at the Society’s Craft Centre at Albert Park.

results.title: Where have all the farms gone?
results.creator_credit: Michael Brun, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Tumbledown, weatherbeaten old barns and dwellings stand like gaunt skeletons of other times, reproachful of an economy that let them down. Unable to compete with food-chain marketing, the farmers have moved into town, and eventually the bulldozer applies the final indignity to buildings that once represented a full and wholesome way of life. Filmed in 1969 in the Upper Ottawa Valley of Ontario and Quebec, this film carries nostalgia in its mute question: What price progress?
